elements.content: Inorganic functionalization of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), such as incorporation of multiple inorganic building blocks with distinct metals into one structure and further modulation of the metal charges, endows the porous materials with significant properties toward their applications in catalysis. In this work, by an exploration of the role of 4-pyrazolecarboxylic acid (H2PyC) in the formation of trinuclear copper pyrazolate as a metalloligand in situ, four new MOFs with multiple components in order were constructed through one-pot synthesis. This metalloligand strategy provides multicomponent MOFs with new topologies (tub for FDM-4 and tap for FDM-5) and is also compatible with a second organic linker for cooperative construction of complex MOFs (1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid for FDM-6 and 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid for FDM-7). The component multiplicity of these MOFs originates from PyC’s ability to separate Cu and Zn on the basis of their differentiated binding affinities toward pyrazolate and carboxylate. These MOFs feature reversible and facile redox transformations between CuI 3(PyC)3 and CuII 3(μ-OH)­(PyC)3(OH)3 without altering the connecting geometries of the units, thus further contributing to the significant catalytic activities in the oxidation of CO and aromatic alcohols and the decomposition of H2O2. This study on programming multiple inorganic components into one framework and modulating their electronic structures is an example of functionalizing the inorganic units of MOFs with a high degree of control.

The component multiplicity of these MOFs originates from PyC's ability to separate Cu and Zn on the basis of their differentiated binding affinities toward pyrazolate and carboxylate. These MOFs feature reversible and facile redox transformations between CuI 3(PyC)3 and CuII 3(μ-OH)(PyC)3(OH)3 without altering the connecting geometries of the units, thus further contributing to the significant catalytic activities in the oxidation of CO and aromatic alcohols and the decomposition of H2O2. This study on programming multiple inorganic components into one framework and modulating their electronic structures is an example of functionalizing the inorganic units of MOFs with a high degree of control.

elements.content: The reticular chemistry of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) has been greatly enriched by attaching specific functional groups to the organic linkers using presynthetic or postsynthetic approaches, and recently the strategy of using more than one linker in one pot has provided MOFs with multiple organic components and multivariate MOFs (MTV-MOFs). Compared with the various methods for organic functionalization of MOF structures, methods for inorganic functionalization, such as incorporating more than one metal in the framework or regulating the electronic structures of specific inorganic building blocks (such as switching the metal charge) in a controlled manner, have been less explored but have gained increasing recognition.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The reticular chemistry of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) has been greatly enriched by attaching specific functional groups to the organic linkers using presynthetic or postsynthetic approaches, and recently the strategy of using more than one linker in one pot has provided MOFs with multiple organic components and multivariate MOFs (MTV-MOFs). Compared with the various methods for organic functionalization of MOF structures, methods for inorganic functionalization, such as incorporating more than one metal in the framework or regulating the electronic structures of specific inorganic building blocks (such as switching the metal charge) in a controlled manner, have been less explored but have gained increasing recognition.

elements.content: We sought to pursue multicomponent MOFs in which (i) different metal ions are organized into distinct secondary building units (SBUs) through one-pot synthesis and (ii) the metals from these SBUs present switchable redox states while preserving the SBU geometry. Recently, 4-pyrazolecarboxylic acid (H2PyC) as an organic linker has drawn our great attention because the pyrazole and carboxylic acid feature distinguishable coordination affinities toward different metal ions. Therefore, in addition to the frequently observed entities from three pyrazoles and three metals, such as Cu, this binding divergence creates a second SBU based on a different metal on the carboxylic acid side. Furthermore, the trinuclear entities with different metal valences, [CuI 3(HPyC)3] (3a in ; the number 3 indicates the connectivity of the SBU) and [CuII 3(μ-OH)­(HPyC)3]2+ (3b in ), carry exactly the same SBU geometry in the resulting frameworks, thus guaranteeing the integrity of the structures during the oxidation and reduction. By the use of this characteristic building block, open and multicomponent structures could be rationally programed and synthesized, in which further modulation of the metal valence and consequent unusual catalytic activities in compartmentalized spaces are expected.

elements.content: Construction of multicomponent FDM-3–7 using SBUs with distinct geometries. By the use of triangular CuI 3(HPyC)3 (3a) or CuII 3(μ-OH)­(HPyC)3 (3b), Zn2(COO)3 (3c), square-pyramidal Zn4O­(COO)4R (5a, 5b), trigonal-bipyramidal Zn2(COO)4(NN) (5c), and octahedral Zn4O­(COO)3R3 (6a–6e), five multicomponent MOFs with different topologies were synthesized. Mesopores in FDM-3–7 are shown as yellow and orange spheres. R = COO or NN.

By the use of triangular CuI 3(HPyC)3 (3a) or CuII 3(μ-OH)(HPyC)3 (3b), Zn2(COO)3 (3c), square-pyramidal Zn4O(COO)4R (5a, 5b), trigonal-bipyramidal Zn2(COO)4(NN) (5c), and octahedral Zn4O(COO)3R3 (6a-6e), five multicomponent MOFs with different topologies were synthesized. Mesopores in FDM-3-7 are shown as yellow and orange spheres. R = COO or NN.

elements.content: In this work, we successfully synthesized two multicomponent MOFs with unprecedented topologies, namely, FDM-4 and FDM-5 (FDM = Fudan material), by combining H2PyC as the only organic ligand, various Zn-based SBUs, and the triangular copper pyrazolate complex in situ as the metalloligand in one pot. This synthetic strategy was further exemplified in the construction of two new MOFs, FDM-6 and FDM-7, where two types of struts with distinct geometriesthe triangular metalloligand and the linear organic linkerwere consolidated in an ordered fashion. Driven by the coordination pairing between the two metal ions and the two ends of PyC, the self-organization of the various building blocks achieved complex MOFs with as many as four components. All four MOFs feature micropores and mesopores with Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface areas as high as 3728 m2 g–1, despite the short linker used. The triangular building units in these MOFs undergo modulated redox reactions between CuI 3(PyC)3 and CuII 3(μ-OH)­(PyC)3(OH)3 reversibly without changing the underlying geometries of the units, as monitored by single-crystal X-ray diffraction and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy. Complete oxidation of CO to CO2 and size-selective oxidation of aromatic alcohols demonstrated the Cu­(I) sites’ high activities at both the solid–gas and solid–solution interfaces. Furthermore, the facile interchangeability of Cu­(I) and Cu­(II) in these MOFs was investigated by their remarkable catalytic performances in H2O2 decomposition. Overall, the MOF design principles presented here provide a systematic approach to program multiple components into one single crystal with high porosity; by further investigation of the electronic communications between the precisely arranged components, these redox-active MOFs promise emerging catalytic properties.

elements.content: The trinuclear complex entities [CuI 3(HPyC)3] (3a in ) and [CuII 3(μ-OH)­(HPyC)3]2+ (3b in ) can act as tritopic carboxylate-based building blocks in MOF synthesis. With a spacer expansion of 3.3 Å along three directions compared with 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC), these metalloligands made from H2PyC allow the formation of MOF structures with higher porosity. Furthermore, unlike another frequently used organic linker, 1,3,5-tris­(4-carboxyphenyl)­benzene (H3BTB), all of the carboxylates in the Cu-based metalloligands are in coplanar conformation, making the construction of new MOFs with high symmetry more feasible. Most importantly, H2PyC is capable of separating and organizing different metal ions into SBUs with distinct geometries in a one-pot reaction, as demonstrated previously in the synthesis of FDM-3. Recently we further explored the metalloligand strategy and successfully constructed a series of MOFs with multiple components based on the trinuclear Cu-based building blocks.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis of Multicomponent MOFs with New Topologies Using the Metalloligand Strategy

The trinuclear complex entities [CuI 3(HPyC)3] (3a in ) and [CuII 3(μ-OH)(HPyC)3]2+ (3b in ) can act as tritopic carboxylate-based building blocks in MOF synthesis. With a spacer expansion of 3.3 Å along three directions compared with 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC), these metalloligands made from H2PyC allow the formation of MOF structures with higher porosity. Furthermore, unlike another frequently used organic linker, 1,3,5-tris(4-carboxyphenyl)benzene (H3BTB), all of the carboxylates in the Cu-based metalloligands are in coplanar conformation, making the construction of new MOFs with high symmetry more feasible. Most importantly, H2PyC is capable of separating and organizing different metal ions into SBUs with distinct geometries in a one-pot reaction, as demonstrated previously in the synthesis of FDM-3. Recently we further explored the metalloligand strategy and successfully constructed a series of MOFs with multiple components based on the trinuclear Cu-based building blocks.

elements.content: Experimentally, by careful control of the mixed metal ratio of Zn and Cu in the solution with H2PyC, colorless single crystals of FDM-4 ( and a) were synthesized solvothermally (see the Supporting Information (SI)). Single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SXRD) revealed that FDM-4 crystallizes in the hexagonal noncentrosymmetric space group P63 mc (Table S2). In FDM-4, Cu ions coordinate only with the pyrazolates to form the triangular metalloligands, while Zn ions coordinate with all of the carboxylates and some additional pyrazolates. Thus, the network consists of octahedral SBUs based on Zn4O­(COO)6 with four variations (SBUs 6a–c and 6e in ) and the triangular SBU 3a (). This (3,6,6)-coordinated network possesses four kinds of polyhedral cages (a). A small tetrahedral cage (cage 4I) with a size of 5.2 Å is built with four octahedral SBUs as the nodes and six PyC linkers as the edges. Both cage 4II and cage 4III use the Cu-based triangular SBUs (gray in a) and two kinds of topologically distinct Zn-based octahedral SBUs (gold and blue in a) as the nodes, with cage sizes of 7.2 and 11.4 Å, respectively. Interestingly, cages 4II and 4III can be viewed as expanded versions of cage 4I obtained by replacing three or six PyC edges with the metalloligands. The largest cage in FDM-4, cage 4IV, is surrounded by 12 pentagons and four hexagons and is mesoporous with a pore diameter of 24.0 Å. FDM-4 has the same four types of cages as the mixed-linker MOF UMCM-3, but the spatial arrangements of the four cages are different (Figure S1), resulting in a new topology named tub for FDM-4.

elements.content: Topological and cage analysis of FDM-4 and FDM-5. (a) FDM-4 has four kinds of cages arranged in the new tub topology. (b) In FDM-5 with the new tap topology, six octagons are connected by six squares to form one cage with a self-penetrated surface.
elements.clean_text: 2  Topological and cage analysis of FDM-4 and FDM-5. (a) FDM-4 has four kinds of cages arranged in the new tub topology. (b) In FDM-5 with the new tap topology, six octagons are connected by six squares to form one cage with a self-penetrated surface.

elements.content: Adjusting the solvothermal reaction conditions slightly, we observed the formation of colorless single crystals of FDM-5. FDM-5 belongs to the tetragonal space group I4/m (Table S2). In addition to the SBU 3a, triangular Zn2(COO)3 (3c) and trigonal-bipyramidal Zn2(COO)4(NN) (5c) building blocks were located in FDM-5 by SXRD ( and b). Despite the multiple building blocks (three kinds of SBUs and one kind of linker) in FDM-5, it features only one type of porous cage. The surface of this cage is surrounded by six octagons composed of 3a and 3c, and they are further bridged by six squares using 5c as the nodes (b). Interestingly, the stacking of metalloligands 3a with each other (Cu–Cu distance of 3.52 Å from neighboring 3a; see Figure S2) and the non-coplanarity of the octagons make the framework self-penetrated (b). With the inner size of the mesoporous cage 5I being 20.6 Å × 34.3 Å, the topology of (3,3,5)-coordinated FDM-5 is the unprecedented tap topology.

elements.content: FDM-4 and FDM-5 are examples of making multicomponent MOFs with new topologies by combining (i) the versatility in constructing Zn-based SBUs with distinct geometries and (ii) the straightforwardness in obtaining rigid Cu-based metalloligands with H2PyC only as the ligand. However, whether the metalloligand strategy applies to systems involving H2PyC and another organic linker remains unexplored on account of the difficulties in consolidating the two types of linkers (the organic ligand and metalloligand) into one crystallization process simultaneously. To address this challenge, we synthesized FDM-6 and FDM-7 by introducing a second organic linker (1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BDC) for FDM-6 and 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid (2,6-H2NDC) for FDM-7) into the reactions with Cu, Zn, and H2PyC ( and ). In FDM-6 (Table S2), each octahedral 6a is coordinated with four triangular 3b and two BDC, resulting in a framework isoreticular to (3,6)-coordinated UMCM-2 with a topology of umt. In FDM-6, the ratio of the SBU 3b–6a distance (9.74 Å) to the SBU 6a–6a distance (13.02 Å) is 1:1.34, as determined by the lengths of PyC and BDC. This value is almost the same as the corresponding edge length ratio in UMCM-2 (1:1.37). In addition to the length ratio match, the identical geometry of the metalloligand in FDM-6 and the BTB in UMCM-2 guides these two structures to be assembled with the same topology. Crystallized in the hexagonal space group P63/m, FDM-6 features an extraordinary five kinds of cages, the microporous cages 6I–6III (7.0, 8.8, and 13.0 Å × 19.0 Å in size, respectively) and the mesoporous cages 6IV and 6V (20.2 Å × 23.4 Å and 20.4 Å × 31.0 Å in size, respectively). The dodecahedral cage 6IV has eight 6a and 12 3b as the nodes, and cage 6V is a pentadecahedron with three hexagons and 12 pentagons.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Multicomponent MOFs by Metalloligand and Organic Ligand Mixing

FDM-4 and FDM-5 are examples of making multicomponent MOFs with new topologies by combining (i) the versatility in constructing Zn-based SBUs with distinct geometries and (ii) the straightforwardness in obtaining rigid Cu-based metalloligands with H2PyC only as the ligand. However, whether the metalloligand strategy applies to systems involving H2PyC and another organic linker remains unexplored on account of the difficulties in consolidating the two types of linkers (the organic ligand and metalloligand) into one crystallization process simultaneously. To address this challenge, we synthesized FDM-6 and FDM-7 by introducing a second organic linker (1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BDC) for FDM-6 and 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid (2,6-H2NDC) for FDM-7) into the reactions with Cu, Zn, and H2PyC ( and ). In FDM-6 (Table S2), each octahedral 6a is coordinated with four triangular 3b and two BDC, resulting in a framework isoreticular to (3,6)-coordinated UMCM-2 with a topology of umt. In FDM-6, the ratio of the SBU 3b-6a distance (9.74 Å) to the SBU 6a-6a distance (13.02 Å) is 1:1.34, as determined by the lengths of PyC and BDC. This value is almost the same as the corresponding edge length ratio in UMCM-2 (1:1.37). In addition to the length ratio match, the identical geometry of the metalloligand in FDM-6 and the BTB in UMCM-2 guides these two structures to be assembled with the same topology. Crystallized in the hexagonal space group P63/m, FDM-6 features an extraordinary five kinds of cages, the microporous cages 6I-6III (7.0, 8.8, and 13.0 Å × 19.0 Å in size, respectively) and the mesoporous cages 6IV and 6V (20.2 Å × 23.4 Å and 20.4 Å × 31.0 Å in size, respectively). The dodecahedral cage 6IV has eight 6a and 12 3b as the nodes, and cage 6V is a pentadecahedron with three hexagons and 12 pentagons.

elements.content: Topological and cage analysis of FDM-6 and FDM-7. (a) FDM-6 features five kinds of cages, and (b) FDM-7 has three kinds of cages in the network.
elements.clean_text: 3  Topological and cage analysis of FDM-6 and FDM-7. (a) FDM-6 features five kinds of cages, and (b) FDM-7 has three kinds of cages in the network.

elements.content: On the other hand, FDM-7 ( and b and Table S2) contains the metalloligand (3b), one octahedral SBU with two variations (6a and 6b), and two kinds of linear dicarboxylic acids with different lengths (PyC and NDC) in the network. Specifically, PyC has two roles in the FDM-7 construction: (i) participating in the formation of the triangular metalloligand and (ii) serving as the linear ditopic linker. Indeed, PyC also has this dual role in FDM-3–5, whereas PyC in FDM-6 is involved only in the metalloligand construction. As a result, the arrangement of these four distinct components in order spontaneously creates three different types of cages in FDM-7. Cages 7I and 7II have the same faces, but the edge length difference between PyC and NDC creates pores with different shapes (7.2 Å × 7.2 Å and 5.2 Å × 11.2 Å, respectively). The largest cage in FDM-7, cage 7III, with a size of 18.4 Å × 21.6 Å, has the same [512] tiling as the dodecahedral cage 6IV. This quaternary MOF is analogous to MOF-205 and MUF-7 with the ith-d topology, but it avoids the use of a costly tricarboxylic acid such as H3BTB. Overall, the construction of three-component FDM-6 and four-component FDM-7 has expanded the metalloligand strategy to mixed linker systems successfully. It can be concluded that the metalloligand and the organic linker share similar assembly kinetics under common MOF synthesis conditions and could be rationally incorporated into multicomponent MOFs with high complexity in a single phase.

elements.content: It should be emphasized that for the synthesis of FDM-3–7, the ratio between Cu­(NO3)2·3H2O and H2PyC in the starting material was kept at around 1:2 and the concentration of Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O was at least 15 times higher than that of Cu­(NO3)2·3H2O. This was done to make sure that all of the Cu ions coordinate with the pyrazolates but not with the carboxylates. In general, a higher concentration of Cu ion may lead to the formation of MOF-325 as the byproduct, which is based on the metalloligand 3b and the Cu2(COO)4 SBU. Under the optimized conditions, we were able to synthesize FDM-3–7 all in pure phases, as evidenced by the powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analyses (Figures S3–S6).
elements.clean_text: It should be emphasized that for the synthesis of FDM-3-7, the ratio between Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O and H2PyC in the starting material was kept at around 1:2 and the concentration of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O was at least 15 times higher than that of Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O. This was done to make sure that all of the Cu ions coordinate with the pyrazolates but not with the carboxylates. In general, a higher concentration of Cu ion may lead to the formation of MOF-325 as the byproduct, which is based on the metalloligand 3b and the Cu2(COO)4 SBU. Under the optimized conditions, we were able to synthesize FDM-3-7 all in pure phases, as evidenced by the powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analyses (Figures S3-S6).

elements.content: As can be seen from the single-crystal structures, the mesoporous cages 4IV, 5I, 6IV, 6V, and 7III in FDM-4–7 contribute to the mesoporosity of the MOFs. To evaluate the porosity of these MOFs, we measured the N2 adsorption isotherms of the activated samples at 77 K (; see the SI for the sample activation procedures). The BET surface areas of FDM-4–7 are 3393, 1067, 3728, and 3423 m2 g–1, respectively. We provide the complete pore analysis in and Figures S7–S10, and here we describe the particular case of FDM-6 containing five different types of cages as an illustrative example. With a Langmuir surface area of 4269 m2 g–1, FDM-6 has a high calculated void percentage of 82% based on the crystal structure, and the pore volume is 1.43 cm3 g–1 based on the isotherm. FDM-6’s void percentage ranks in the same category with several benchmark MOF materials, such as MOF-5 (79%), MIL-101 (81%), and MOF-177 (83%). In the pore size distribution profile (Figure S9), two distinct ranges were observed (micropores with diameters of 1.0–1.5 nm and mesopores at 2.0–3.1 nm), corresponding to the microporous cages 6I–III and mesoporous cages 6IV and 6V. Even though the length of PyC is only 4.2 Å, consolidating two metal ions with distinct coordination preferences and geometries into complex MOFs has made these structures mesoporous with high surface areas.
elements.clean_text:
Mesoporosity of FDM-4-7 Based on Short Struts

As can be seen from the single-crystal structures, the mesoporous cages 4IV, 5I, 6IV, 6V, and 7III in FDM-4-7 contribute to the mesoporosity of the MOFs. To evaluate the porosity of these MOFs, we measured the N2 adsorption isotherms of the activated samples at 77 K (; see the SI for the sample activation procedures). The BET surface areas of FDM-4-7 are 3393, 1067, 3728, and 3423 m2 g-1, respectively. We provide the complete pore analysis in  and Figures S7-S10, and here we describe the particular case of FDM-6 containing five different types of cages as an illustrative example. With a Langmuir surface area of 4269 m2 g-1, FDM-6 has a high calculated void percentage of 82% based on the crystal structure, and the pore volume is 1.43 cm3 g-1 based on the isotherm. FDM-6's void percentage ranks in the same category with several benchmark MOF materials, such as MOF-5 (79%), MIL-101 (81%), and MOF-177 (83%). In the pore size distribution profile (Figure S9), two distinct ranges were observed (micropores with diameters of 1.0-1.5 nm and mesopores at 2.0-3.1 nm), corresponding to the microporous cages 6I-III and mesoporous cages 6IV and 6V. Even though the length of PyC is only 4.2 Å, consolidating two metal ions with distinct coordination preferences and geometries into complex MOFs has made these structures mesoporous with high surface areas.

Interestingly, all of the FDM-4–7 crystals were colorless when they were first crystallized in capped vials (a), indicating that Cu­(II) ions from cupric nitrate were reduced during the synthesis and that the Cu in these as-synthesized MOF structures is monovalent. A close re-examination of the previously reported FDM-3 recorded the same observation. Reduction of Cu­(II) to Cu­(I) is not rare in MOF synthesis and is possibly assisted by the solvent as the reductant. However, to our surprise, after the vial caps were loosened, the crystal color transformed to light blue immediately for all five MOFs, suggesting that some Cu­(I) ions in the framework were oxidized to Cu­(II) upon contact with ambient air (b). In view of this, we performed the FDM-6 synthesis in a sealed tube filled with N2. The formed FDM-6 crystals remained colorless for weeks until the tube was opened, indicating that the Cu­(I) in the MOF structure is stable until it comes into contact with air.
elements.clean_text:
Oxidation and Reduction of Cu in the Triangular Building Blocks

Interestingly, all of the FDM-4-7 crystals were colorless when they were first crystallized in capped vials (a), indicating that Cu(II) ions from cupric nitrate were reduced during the synthesis and that the Cu in these as-synthesized MOF structures is monovalent. A close re-examination of the previously reported FDM-3 recorded the same observation. Reduction of Cu(II) to Cu(I) is not rare in MOF synthesis and is possibly assisted by the solvent as the reductant. However, to our surprise, after the vial caps were loosened, the crystal color transformed to light blue immediately for all five MOFs, suggesting that some Cu(I) ions in the framework were oxidized to Cu(II) upon contact with ambient air (b). In view of this, we performed the FDM-6 synthesis in a sealed tube filled with N2. The formed FDM-6 crystals remained colorless for weeks until the tube was opened, indicating that the Cu(I) in the MOF structure is stable until it comes into contact with air.

elements.content: The fast oxidation addresses a challenge in the accurate structure determination of the Cu-based SBUs in these MOFs by SXRD. Depending on the length of air contact time before and during data collection, partial or full oxidation of Cu­(I) occurs, and therefore, different SBUs (3a or 3b in ) were presented. In the reported structures from SXRD, FDM-4 and FDM-5 feature 3a units in the frameworks; on the other hand, FDM-6 and FDM-7 have 3b as the building blocks, in which the square-planar coordination geometry of Cu­(II) is fulfilled by OH– as the terminal ligand. However, considering that all of the pristine crystals are colorless, we propose that the as-synthesized FDM-3–7 have the CuI 3(PyC)3 units as the building blocks and that they are oxidized to CuII 3(μ-OH)­(PyC)3 upon exposure to the ambient air.

In the reported structures from SXRD, FDM-4 and FDM-5 feature 3a units in the frameworks; on the other hand, FDM-6 and FDM-7 have 3b as the building blocks, in which the square-planar coordination geometry of Cu(II) is fulfilled by OH- as the terminal ligand. However, considering that all of the pristine crystals are colorless, we propose that the as-synthesized FDM-3-7 have the CuI 3(PyC)3 units as the building blocks and that they are oxidized to CuII 3(μ-OH)(PyC)3 upon exposure to the ambient air.

elements.content: On the basis of the single-crystal structures, CHN elemental analyses, and ICP-AES results (see the SI for details), we conclude that the as-synthesized MOFs based on CuI 3(PyC)3, fully oxidized MOFs based on CuII 3(μ-OH)­(PyC)3, and mixed-charge MOFs based on CuI x CuII 3–x (μ-OH)1–x/3(PyC)3(OH)3–x (x = 0–3) have the formulas shown in Table S1. For example, the formula of as-synthesized FDM-4 is {(Zn4O)5[CuI 3(PyC)3]6(PyC)6}·[Zn­(OH)2(H2O)2]6. When FDM-4 is fully oxidized, the formula changes to {(Zn4O)5[CuII 3(μ-OH)­(PyC)3]6(PyC)6(OH)18}·[Zn­(OH)­(H2O)3]6. It is noteworthy that one OH– from the isolated Zn-based complex that stays in the pores to compensate for the charge but could not be located by SXRD, is substituted with H2O to keep the MOF structure neutral upon oxidation.

For example, the formula of as-synthesized FDM-4 is {(Zn4O)5[CuI 3(PyC)3]6(PyC)6}⋅[Zn(OH)2(H2O)2]6. When FDM-4 is fully oxidized, the formula changes to {(Zn4O)5[CuII 3(μ-OH)(PyC)3]6(PyC)6(OH)18}⋅[Zn(OH)(H2O)3]6. It is noteworthy that one OH- from the isolated Zn-based complex that stays in the pores to compensate for the charge but could not be located by SXRD, is substituted with H2O to keep the MOF structure neutral upon oxidation.

elements.content: X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) is a powerful tool to examine the valence of Cu in FDM-3–7, and it shows mixed charge for all five MOFs even with minimum exposure to the air during the MOF drying process (wash with N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF), solvent exchange with CH2Cl2, and then vacuum-dry at room temperature). Specifically, as shown in c, an intense asymmetrical Cu 2p3/2 photoelectron peak along with satellite peaks indicate the mixed-valence state of Cu in FDM-6. This peak can be deconvoluted into two contributions located at 932.9 and 934.4 eV, corresponding to Cu­(I) 2p3/2 and Cu­(II) 2p3/2, respectively. Integration of the Cu­(I) 2p3/2 peak and the Cu­(II) 2p3/2 peak with Cu­(II) satellite peaks (941.4 and 944.3 eV) gives the calculated Cu­(I):Cu­(II) ratio as ∼2.0:1.0 in FDM-6. The other investigated MOFs also show mixed-valence state of Cu, with the Cu­(I):Cu­(II) ratios in FDM-3, -4, -5, and -7 being ∼1.1:1.9, 2.2:0.8, 1.0:2.0, and 1.3:1.7, respectively (Figures S11, S13, S15, and S17). These results suggest that FDM-3–7, featuring the same Cu-based SBUs but with completely different spatial arrangements of the SBUs and distinct local electronic structures around these SBUs, show varied oxidation rates even when the same sample drying procedure with similar air exposure times was applied. Interestingly, complete oxidation of these MOFs within a short period could be achieved by adding additional oxidants, as indicated by the appearance of only Cu­(II) 2p3/2 peaks (933.4 eV in Figure S19, 933.6 eV in Figure S20, and 933.7 eV in Figure S21) in the cases of FDM-4 and FDM-6 oxidized with H2O2 and FDM-3 oxidized with Ag+, respectively.

The other investigated MOFs also show mixed-valence state of Cu, with the Cu(I):Cu(II) ratios in FDM-3, -4, -5, and -7 being ~1.1:1.9, 2.2:0.8, 1.0:2.0, and 1.3:1.7, respectively (Figures S11, S13, S15, and S17). elements.content: Most of the reports on MOFs with Cu-based triangular SBUs suggest that the oxidation state of Cu is either 2+ or 1+, with 2+ dominant in the literature. A few structures made from bipyrazole show very slow oxidation of Cu­(I) in the air, as indicated by the mild color change of the crystals. However, FDM-3–7 are the first MOF examples where the oxidation of Cu­(I) happens rapidly and can be quantatively monitored by XPS. In FDM-3–7, the Zn­(II)–carboxylate coordination bonding withdraws electrons from the PyC linker, which makes the Cu­(I) on the other end of PyC more prone to be attacked by the nucleophiles, thus facilitating the activation of dioxygen molecules and the oxidation of Cu­(I). With the distance between N from pyrazole and O from carboxylic acid as short as 4.2 Å, the PyC bridging ligand between two metals allows substantial electronic communication and thus influences the redox behavior of each of the Cu­(I) site in the framework. The multicomponent nature of these MOFs provides an ideal platform to further fine-tune the redox properties of the structures by controlling their arrangements in three-dimensional space and studying the electronic effects of each of the building units.

elements.content: Interestingly, when the partially oxidized FDM-3–7 were activated by heating at 200 °C under vacuum, the crystal color turned light yellow for all five MOFs. The XPS spectra show that the percentage of Cu ions existing as Cu­(I) in these MOFs increased after the activation, indicating reduction of Cu­(II) to Cu­(I). Specifically, as shown in Figures S12, S14, , and S18, thermally activated FDM-3, -4, -6, and -7 exhibited only intense sharp Cu­(I) 2p3/2 peaks at 933.0, 932.6, 933.2, and 933.0 eV, respectively, without satellite peaks, implying that all of the Cu­(II) ions were reduced to Cu­(I). For FDM-5, the reduction was not complete after thermal treatment, despite the increase in the percentage of Cu­(I) ions from ∼33% to ∼73% (Figure S16). What is more, the reduction could be trigged not only by heating but also by mild reductive solvent. All of the partially oxidized MOFs could be turned back to colorless upon heating in N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP) at 160 °C for less than 10 min, indicating complete reduction to Cu­(I). With the conversion from SBU 3a to 3b and back to 3a along the oxidation and reduction sequence, the frameworks of FDM-4–7 still retained their crystallinity with the same respective unit cell parameters, as validated by the coincidence of the experimental PXRD patterns of the thermally activated samples with their simulation (Figures S3–S6).

Specifically, as shown in Figures S12, S14, , and S18, thermally activated FDM-3, -4, -6, and -7 exhibited only intense sharp Cu(I) 2p3/2 peaks at 933.0, 932.6, 933.2, and 933.0 eV, respectively, without satellite peaks, implying that all of the Cu(II) ions were reduced to Cu(I). For FDM-5, the reduction was not complete after thermal treatment, despite the increase in the percentage of Cu(I) ions from ~33% to ~73% (Figure S16). What is more, the reduction could be trigged not only by heating but also by mild reductive solvent. elements.content: We picked FDM-6 to further study the reversibility of the Cu­(I)/Cu­(II) transformation in these frameworks. Within our expectation, exposing thermally activated FDM-6 to the air results in the color change to blue again. However, compared with the as-synthesized FDM-6, the activated sample is more resistant to oxidation in ambient air, as evidenced by the apparent slower color change of the crystals. This is possibly due to the lack of nucleophiles such as water in the pores. To prove this, we placed the light-yellow crystals of reduced FDM-6 in a glovebox filled with oxygen, and the crystal color remained unchanged, confirming that H2O is needed to convert Cu­(I) to Cu­(II) upon contact with O2. In summary, as proposed in , the linear-coordinated Cu­(I) ions in CuI 3(PyC)3 are oxidized under O2 and H2O, and the trinuclear SBU evolves into CuII 3(μ-OH)­(PyC)3(OH)3. This reaction can be reversed by heating under vacuum or with mild reducing agent (see the SI for the full equation).

elements.content: The study of carbon monoxide oxidation over Cu-based catalysts has its significance in exhaust emission control. Cu­(I) is known to catalyze the oxidation of CO by the use of valence variation to seize or release oxygen readily. With all of the Cu­(I) sites accessible in the activated FDM-3–7, we investigated their catalytic activities in CO oxidation using a fixed-bed flow reactor. CO (1% in air) was passed through the bed after the MOFs were pretreated in He at 200 °C for 2 h, and the effluent gases were analyzed by GC. a shows that the activated FDM-3–7 can catalyze the oxidation of CO, with complete conversion to CO2 at ∼210 °C for FDM-4 and ∼220 °C for FDM-3, -6, and -7. The PXRD patterns of these four MOFs after CO oxidation at up to 240 °C showed that all of the peaks corresponded to the pristine MOF structures (Figures S23, S24, S26, and S27), suggesting that the MOFs retain their structures during the reactions. Furthermore, no peak from either Cu2O or CuO was observed, confirming that the catalytic active sites are the triangular Cu-based modules, which are accessible to CO guests. In the case of activated FDM-5, full conversion was not achieved, probably because of the relative instability of the bimetallic SBUs Zn2(COO)3 (3c) and Zn2(COO)4(NN) (5c) at high temperature, as evidenced by the early weight loss in thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) (Figure S22) and peak disappearance in the PXRD pattern after CO oxidation (Figure S25).
elements.clean_text:
Oxidation of Carbon Monoxide by FDM-3-7

The study of carbon monoxide oxidation over Cu-based catalysts has its significance in exhaust emission control. Cu(I) is known to catalyze the oxidation of CO by the use of valence variation to seize or release oxygen readily. With all of the Cu(I) sites accessible in the activated FDM-3-7, we investigated their catalytic activities in CO oxidation using a fixed-bed flow reactor. CO (1% in air) was passed through the bed after the MOFs were pretreated in He at 200 °C for 2 h, and the effluent gases were analyzed by GC. a shows that the activated FDM-3-7 can catalyze the oxidation of CO, with complete conversion to CO2 at ~210 °C for FDM-4 and ~220 °C for FDM-3, -6, and -7. The PXRD patterns of these four MOFs after CO oxidation at up to 240 °C showed that all of the peaks corresponded to the pristine MOF structures (Figures S23, S24, S26, and S27), suggesting that the MOFs retain their structures during the reactions. Furthermore, no peak from either Cu2O or CuO was observed, confirming that the catalytic active sites are the triangular Cu-based modules, which are accessible to CO guests. In the case of activated FDM-5, full conversion was not achieved, probably because of the relative instability of the bimetallic SBUs Zn2(COO)3 (3c) and Zn2(COO)4(NN) (5c) at high temperature, as evidenced by the early weight loss in thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) (Figure S22) and peak disappearance in the PXRD pattern after CO oxidation (Figure S25).

elements.content: The temperature required for 50% CO conversion (T 1/2) was 200, 180, 215, 195, and 190 °C for FDM-3–7, respectively. Our control studies on CuII 2(COO)4-based HKUST-1 activated by heating at 200 °C under vacuum showed no activity at 200 °C. Although HKUST-1 activated at higher temperatures (230 and 250 °C) have shown CO oxidation activities below 200 °C previously, it is unclear whether the activity is due to reduced Cu­(I) in the framework or Cu2O from the decomposition of HKUST-1. Overall, compared with HKUST-1 and a reported copper pyrazolatecarboxylate MOF with redox-inactive Cu­(II)-based units under similar activation methods, a lower temperature was recorded for 100% CO conversion using the MOFs presented. We conclude that the elevated performance is due to the high density of Cu­(I) sites in the framework and their aptness in valence variation during the conversion. In addition, the high surface areas and large pore openings of mesoporous FDM-3–7 guarantee the accessibility of active sites and free diffusion of CO, O2, and CO2.

elements.content: The interaction between CO and Cu sites in FDM-3–7 was further studied by in situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS). b shows the DRIFTS spectra of the FDM-7 after three stepwise treatments (preheated at 200 °C for 2 h under He, exposed to 5 vol % CO flow for 30 min, and purged with He for 15 min after CO exposure), and the DRIFTS spectra for the other MOFs are provided in Figures S28–S31. After FDM-7 was exposed to CO, two peaks at 2171 and 2109 cm–1 were observed. Upon purging with He, the peak at 2171 cm–1 disappeared, and the peak at 2109 cm–1 shifted slightly to 2105 cm–1. It is known that CO adsorption on Cu2+ or Cu0 is very weak and that the adsorbed CO can be easily removed by purging at room temperature. Thus, the remaining peak at 2105 cm–1 can be assigned to the stretching vibration of the typical C–O bond after CO chemisorption on Cu­(I) sites. For FDM-3–6, similar DRIFTS results were obtained, confirming the strong interaction between CO and the Cu­(I) sites in the MOFs and the subsequent CO activation.

elements.content: The interchangeability of Cu valences in FDM-3–7 drove us to further evaluate their catalytic performances in H2O2 decomposition. Transition-metal-catalyzed decomposition of H2O2 into H2O and O2 usually involves redox-active species, such as Cu­(II)/Cu­(I) sites in Cu–amine complexes or Fe­(III)/Fe­(II) sites in iron oxide. When H2O2 (30% in H2O, 1.0 mL) was added to activated FDM-3 (∼0.1 mmol of Cu sites) in DMF, O2 bubbles vigorously emerged from the surface of the MOF crystals immediately, and the gas-evolving process continued for up to 24 h (Video S1). FDM-4–7 showed similar catalytic activities in H2O2 decomposition as activated FDM-3, confirming that the decomposition is catalyzed by the same Cu-based triangular building blocks. In contrast, an experiment performed on activated HKUST-1 showed no release of O2 from the crystals (Video S2), indicating that the decomposition of H2O2 cannot be catalyzed by Lewis acidic Cu­(II) sites as in HKUST-1 but only by redox-active Cu­(II)/Cu­(I) sites as in FDM-3–7. It is worth noting that the crystal color turned darker at the initial H2O2 decomposition stage, indicating that some Cu­(I) ions were possibly oxidized to Cu­(II) by the O2 released.
elements.clean_text:
H2O2 Decomposition Catalyzed by FDM-3-7

The interchangeability of Cu valences in FDM-3-7 drove us to further evaluate their catalytic performances in H2O2 decomposition. Transition-metal-catalyzed decomposition of H2O2 into H2O and O2 usually involves redox-active species, such as Cu(II)/Cu(I) sites in Cu-amine complexes or Fe(III)/Fe(II) sites in iron oxide. When H2O2 (30% in H2O, 1.0 mL) was added to activated FDM-3 (~0.1 mmol of Cu sites) in DMF, O2 bubbles vigorously emerged from the surface of the MOF crystals immediately, and the gas-evolving process continued for up to 24 h (Video S1). FDM-4-7 showed similar catalytic activities in H2O2 decomposition as activated FDM-3, confirming that the decomposition is catalyzed by the same Cu-based triangular building blocks. In contrast, an experiment performed on activated HKUST-1 showed no release of O2 from the crystals (Video S2), indicating that the decomposition of H2O2 cannot be catalyzed by Lewis acidic Cu(II) sites as in HKUST-1 but only by redox-active Cu(II)/Cu(I) sites as in FDM-3-7. It is worth noting that the crystal color turned darker at the initial H2O2 decomposition stage, indicating that some Cu(I) ions were possibly oxidized to Cu(II) by the O2 released.

elements.content: With the help of stirring, the H2O2 decomposition rate can be accelerated, decreasing the reaction time to less than 6 h for the aforementioned reaction, with ∼100% H2O2 conversion observed by the time interval measurement of the O2 volume (c). We picked the data from 50 to 100 min after H2O2 contacted with the five MOFs to look at the kinetics of the reaction, for the reasons that (i) during this period the effect of the diffusion barrier of H2O2 into the MOF pores can be considered as constant and (ii) a good amount of released O2 keeps the relative error of the measured O2 volume small. As shown in Figure S32, pseudo-first-order kinetic patterns were observed for all of the H2O2 decompositions catalyzed by the five different MOFs. The k obs of the reactions were (1.64 ± 0.07) × 10–2, (2.00 ± 0.06) × 10–2, (0.66 ± 0.02) × 10–2, (1.24 ± 0.04) × 10–2, and (1.77 ± 0.07) × 10–2 min–1 for FDM-3–7, respectively. Furthermore, the systems still retained their activities for several batches without any regeneration process, as indicated by the full O2 evolution upon injection of H2O2 in equal amounts every 6 h for FDM-4 (d). After five sequential batches, assuming that all of the Cu sites in FDM-4 are active, each Cu site involves at least 500 cycles of rigorous H2O2 conversion without an obvious decrease in the reaction rate. These MOFs lost their high crystallinity after the H2O2 decomposition experiment according to PXRD (Figure S33), indicating possible structural amorphization due to the frequent Cu valence interchange and H2O coordination competition. However, the crystals retained their original shape after the catalysis (without stirring; Figure S34), suggesting that the frameworks still hold their integrity. What is more, the reaction solution remained colorless and no precipitate formed upon addition of Na2S into the supernatant, indicating that no Cu from the framework leached into the solution.

elements.content: Complexes and MOFs based on Cu have been shown to catalyze the aerobic oxidation of benzyl alcohol. One of the proposed mechanisms involving Cu­(I) sites includes their oxidation to Cu­(II) by O2, followed by oxidation of the alcohol to the aldehyde by the Cu­(II) species and cocatalyst. The redox facility and accessibility of the Cu­(I) sites are the key to achieving efficient catalysis. However, MOFs containing accessible and redox-active Cu­(I) sites for alcohol oxidation are scarce, with only one reported example of introducing Cu­(I) sites by postsynthetic modification. With Cu­(I) sites decorating the pore surfaces and taking up more than 19 wt % in the solids, FDM-3–7 were examined as catalysts for the aerobic oxidation of benzyl alcohol in the open air at 70 °C using 2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidin-1-oxyl (TEMPO) and N-methylimidazole (NMI) as cocatalysts, and the yields were checked by 1H NMR spectroscopy. As shown in , without the MOF catalyst, the reaction shows a very low yield (2%); however, all five pristine MOFs investigated showed remarkable catalytic activity in the oxidation of benzyl alcohol to benzaldehyde. Specifically, the yields of benzaldehyde were 98%, >99%, 62%, >99%, and 98% for the reactions catalyzed by activated FDM-3–7 in 24 h. The unsatisfactory yield in the case of FDM-5 is due to the smaller pore opening (with the aperture diagonal of 6.0 Å) and possible lower chemical stability. Indeed, high yields of 70%, 83%, 84%, and 87% were achieved for FDM-3, -4, -6, and -7 as catalysts within the first 12 h. The pores inside these MOFs allow free movement of benzyl alcohol in the crystals and close contact with the active Cu sites without any steric hindrance.
elements.clean_text:
Pristine FDM-3-7 as Benzyl Alcohol Oxidation Catalysts

Complexes and MOFs based on Cu have been shown to catalyze the aerobic oxidation of benzyl alcohol. One of the proposed mechanisms involving Cu(I) sites includes their oxidation to Cu(II) by O2, followed by oxidation of the alcohol to the aldehyde by the Cu(II) species and cocatalyst. The redox facility and accessibility of the Cu(I) sites are the key to achieving efficient catalysis. However, MOFs containing accessible and redox-active Cu(I) sites for alcohol oxidation are scarce, with only one reported example of introducing Cu(I) sites by postsynthetic modification. With Cu(I) sites decorating the pore surfaces and taking up more than 19 wt % in the solids, FDM-3-7 were examined as catalysts for the aerobic oxidation of benzyl alcohol in the open air at 70 °C using 2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidin-1-oxyl (TEMPO) and N-methylimidazole (NMI) as cocatalysts, and the yields were checked by 1H NMR spectroscopy. As shown in , without the MOF catalyst, the reaction shows a very low yield (2%); however, all five pristine MOFs investigated showed remarkable catalytic activity in the oxidation of benzyl alcohol to benzaldehyde. Specifically, the yields of benzaldehyde were 98%, >99%, 62%, >99%, and 98% for the reactions catalyzed by activated FDM-3-7 in 24 h. The unsatisfactory yield in the case of FDM-5 is due to the smaller pore opening (with the aperture diagonal of 6.0 Å) and possible lower chemical stability. Indeed, high yields of 70%, 83%, 84%, and 87% were achieved for FDM-3, -4, -6, and -7 as catalysts within the first 12 h. The pores inside these MOFs allow free movement of benzyl alcohol in the crystals and close contact with the active Cu sites without any steric hindrance.

Pristine FDM-3–7 show great activities in the alcohol oxidation, although our preliminary PXRD studies revealed that the solids lost their crystallinities after the catalytic reaction. We understand that the participation of several Zn–carboxylate-based SBUs (e.g., 3c and 6a) in these MOFs may raise chemical stability issues when they are applied as catalysts in the reactions with TEMPO and NMI. To elucidate the heterogeneous nature of the porous catalysts, we performed substrate size selectivity studies under the same conditions. 3,4,5-Trimethoxybenzyl alcohol (TMBA) was picked for its larger size (∼9.5 Å × 9.2 Å) compared with benzyl alcohol (∼6.0 Å × 4.3 Å). On the basis of the single-crystal structures, FDM-3, -4, -6, and -7 all have pore openings of ∼11.0 Å, which restrain the free movement of TMBA inside the crystals to some extent. Consequently, a drastic drop in the yields (13% for FDM-4 and 15% for FDM-6 in 24 h; ) was observed. These results suggest that the oxidation of benzyl alcohol mainly happens inside the MOF crystals rather than in homogeneous solution and that the size and shape of TMBA molecules made them (i) diffuse very slowly in the pores and (ii) have difficulty in contacting the Cu active sites because of space restriction. Overall, the size and shape selectivity toward the substrates confirms the heterogeneous nature of the MOF catalysts, whose structural character still stands and pore accessibility still remains. With MOF building blocks for higher chemical stability available, research on new structures incorporating these accessible redox-active sites will provide materials with unparalleled catalytic performances.

elements.content: The triangular copper pyrazolate building blocks provide a rational strategy to further explore the multiplicity of structural components in single MOFs, as demonstrated in mesoporous FDM-3–7 with up to four distinct constituents. Furthermore, the classic Cu­(I)/Cu­(II) redox activities of the trinuclear Cu-based modules were inherited after they were apportioned in precise positions throughout the whole porous network. The catalytic performances of these redox-active multicomponent MOFs were verified by the oxidation of CO and aromatic alcohols and the decomposition of H2O2. Akin to the multicopper sites in natural enzymes such as oxidases and oxygenases, the active sites in the MOFs with multiple components under synergy control present their potentials in precision catalysis.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

The triangular copper pyrazolate building blocks provide a rational strategy to further explore the multiplicity of structural components in single MOFs, as demonstrated in mesoporous FDM-3-7 with up to four distinct constituents. Furthermore, the classic Cu(I)/Cu(II) redox activities of the trinuclear Cu-based modules were inherited after they were apportioned in precise positions throughout the whole porous network. The catalytic performances of these redox-active multicomponent MOFs were verified by the oxidation of CO and aromatic alcohols and the decomposition of H2O2. Akin to the multicopper sites in natural enzymes such as oxidases and oxygenases, the active sites in the MOFs with multiple components under synergy control present their potentials in precision catalysis.

cln_elements.content: As can be seen from the single-crystal structures, the mesoporous cages 4IV, 5I, 6IV, 6V, and 7III in FDM-4–7 contribute to the mesoporosity of the MOFs. To evaluate the porosity of these MOFs, we measured the N2 adsorption isotherms of the activated samples at 77 K (; see the SI for the sample activation procedures). The BET surface areas of FDM-4–7 are 3393, 1067, 3728, and 3423 m2 g–1, respectively. We provide the complete pore analysis in and Figures S7–S10, and here we describe the particular case of FDM-6 containing five different types of cages as an illustrative example. With a Langmuir surface area of 4269 m2 g–1, FDM-6 has a high calculated void percentage of 82% based on the crystal structure, and the pore volume is 1.43 cm3 g–1 based on the isotherm. FDM-6’s void percentage ranks in the same category with several benchmark MOF materials, such as MOF-5 (79%), MIL-101 (81%), and MOF-177 (83%). In the pore size distribution profile (Figure S9), two distinct ranges were observed (micropores with diameters of 1.0–1.5 nm and mesopores at 2.0–3.1 nm), corresponding to the microporous cages 6I–III and mesoporous cages 6IV and 6V. Even though the length of PyC is only 4.2 Å, consolidating two metal ions with distinct coordination preferences and geometries into complex MOFs has made these structures mesoporous with high surface areas.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Mesoporosity of FDM-4-7 Based on Short Struts

As can be seen from the single-crystal structures, the mesoporous cages 4IV, 5I, 6IV, 6V, and 7III in FDM-4-7 contribute to the mesoporosity of the MOFs. To evaluate the porosity of these MOFs, we measured the N2 adsorption isotherms of the activated samples at 77 K (; see the SI for the sample activation procedures). The BET surface areas of FDM-4-7 are 3393, 1067, 3728, and 3423 m2 g-1, respectively. We provide the complete pore analysis in  and Figures S7-S10, and here we describe the particular case of FDM-6 containing five different types of cages as an illustrative example. With a Langmuir surface area of 4269 m2 g-1, FDM-6 has a high calculated void percentage of 82% based on the crystal structure, and the pore volume is 1.43 cm3 g-1 based on the isotherm. FDM-6's void percentage ranks in the same category with several benchmark MOF materials, such as MOF-5 (79%), MIL-101 (81%), and MOF-177 (83%). In the pore size distribution profile (Figure S9), two distinct ranges were observed (micropores with diameters of 1.0-1.5 nm and mesopores at 2.0-3.1 nm), corresponding to the microporous cages 6I-III and mesoporous cages 6IV and 6V. Even though the length of PyC is only 4.2 Å, consolidating two metal ions with distinct coordination preferences and geometries into complex MOFs has made these structures mesoporous with high surface areas.

cln_elements.content: Construction of multicomponent FDM-3–7 using SBUs with distinct geometries. By the use of triangular CuI 3(HPyC)3 (3a) or CuII 3(μ-OH)­(HPyC)3 (3b), Zn2(COO)3 (3c), square-pyramidal Zn4O­(COO)4R (5a, 5b), trigonal-bipyramidal Zn2(COO)4(NN) (5c), and octahedral Zn4O­(COO)3R3 (6a–6e), five multicomponent MOFs with different topologies were synthesized. Mesopores in FDM-3–7 are shown as yellow and orange spheres. R = COO or NN.
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  Construction of multicomponent FDM-3-7 using SBUs with distinct geometries. By the use of triangular CuI 3(HPyC)3 (3a) or CuII 3(μ-OH)(HPyC)3 (3b), Zn2(COO)3 (3c), square-pyramidal Zn4O(COO)4R (5a, 5b), trigonal-bipyramidal Zn2(COO)4(NN) (5c), and octahedral Zn4O(COO)3R3 (6a-6e), five multicomponent MOFs with different topologies were synthesized. Mesopores in FDM-3-7 are shown as yellow and orange spheres. R = COO or NN.

cln_elements.content: Topological and cage analysis of FDM-4 and FDM-5. (a) FDM-4 has four kinds of cages arranged in the new tub topology. (b) In FDM-5 with the new tap topology, six octagons are connected by six squares to form one cage with a self-penetrated surface.
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  Topological and cage analysis of FDM-4 and FDM-5. (a) FDM-4 has four kinds of cages arranged in the new tub topology. (b) In FDM-5 with the new tap topology, six octagons are connected by six squares to form one cage with a self-penetrated surface.

cln_elements.content: Topological and cage analysis of FDM-6 and FDM-7. (a) FDM-6 features five kinds of cages, and (b) FDM-7 has three kinds of cages in the network.
